text: to ensure their concoctions are
uniformly mixed cooks use spoons
chemists however use magnetic stir bars
these magnets which are covered by a
non-reactive coating whirl at the bottom
of a reaction flask propelled by a
spinning magnet in a stir plate
but mixing very small amounts of liquid
like the liquid inside a droplet can
pose a problem for scientists who want
to carry out reactions on a microchip
for example
now researchers in singapore have
created the world's smallest magnetic
stir bars
these stir bars are so tiny that they
can mix as little as four pico liters of
liquid that's about one hundred thousand
times smaller than the average raindrop
hong you chen and colleagues at nanyang
technological university
construct these super small stir bars
from iron oxide nanoparticles
these magnetic particles are so small
that it would take more than 12 000 of
them to span the distance across the dot
on the letter i in a newspaper article
the researchers use chemicals to get the
particles to dissolve in water and then
align the particles with a magnet
once they've got their magnetic dots in
a row the researchers give them a
coating of silica the stuff that sand is
made of to hold them together
although the stir bars are too small to
see with the naked eye there are about
400 million of them in the droplet on
the right
when the researchers mix a splotch of
glowing liquid within this droplet and
turn on the magnet the stir bars mix
everything together
you can also see how droplets containing
nanostir bars blink in unison when
sitting atop a rotating magnetic field
and how they align with the magnetic
field when the magnet is rotated
because the super small stir bars are
inexpensive to make and easy to use the
singapore team thinks chemists running
small scale reactions might one day use
them to mix things up in the lab
this is bethany halford reporting for
chemical and engineering news
